childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1967-1979

The smell of Coppertone sunscreen and chlorine. The crackle of a Big Wheel's plastic wheels on hot asphalt. The specific weight of a Tonka truck in your hands—solid steel, heavy enough to do real damage. Your childhood had a texture that safety regulations would later sand down to nothing.

At five, you were watching Mister Rogers' Neighborhood, Electric Company, and Sesame Street when it still had a genuine urban grittiness—Oscar the Grouch lived in an actual trash can on an actual New York street. By seven, you'd graduated to Speed Racer, The Flintstones reruns, and Scooby-Doo. You knew the Harlem Globetrotters cartoon intimately. You had strong opinions about whether Shaggy was a coward or just sensible. (He was sensible.)

Your school supplies were practical and analog. The yellow No. 2 pencil with the pink eraser that smeared more than it erased. The cigar box repurposed as a pencil case. The wide-ruled paper with the dotted line between rows. The mimeograph worksheets that smelled like chemicals and came out purple—you held them to your face and inhaled.

Saturday mornings were sacred. You woke before your parents, poured yourself a bowl of Cap'n Crunch or Quisp, and sat inches from the television. Schoolhouse Rock taught you grammar and history between cartoons—'Conjunction Junction,' 'I'm Just a Bill,' 'Three Is a Magic Number.' You absorbed civics lessons sandwiched between ads for Sea Monkeys and X-Ray Specs.

You ate TV dinners with the compartmentalized trays, Swanson's Hungry-Man with the brownie that was somehow both burnt and frozen. You drank Tang because astronauts drank Tang. You begged for Pop Rocks even after the rumors about the kid whose stomach exploded. You chewed Bazooka Joe gum for the tiny comics. You collected Wacky Packages stickers that mocked the same products your mom bought.

At six, you watched men walk on the moon. You don't remember it clearly, but the grainy image exists somewhere in your memory—the flag, the bounce, the crackly voices. Your parents told you this was history, that you'd remember where you were. They were right.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

Gen X. The name came from a novel and stuck because it captured the blank space—the undefined generation between two cultural juggernauts. You're roughly 65 million Americans, born 1965 to 1980, sandwiched between Boomers who got everything and Millennials who got blamed for everything. You got overlooked, which turned out to be a kind of freedom.

You were one when MLK and RFK were assassinated in 1968. You don't remember it—you were a baby—but you absorbed the aftermath. The optimism of the early '60s didn't exist for you. You only knew what came after: Vietnam on the evening news, Watergate in kindergarten, gas lines in elementary school. Your baseline wasn't hope interrupted; it was cynicism from the start.

Your generation spans the end of the Baby Boom to the dawn of the personal computer era—roughly 65 million Americans who learned to type on actual typewriters and retired on 401(k)s that replaced the pensions you'd been promised. You're the last generation to remember life before cable TV, before VCRs, before the world was always connected.

Divorce rates doubled during your childhood. Latchkey became a word. You came home to empty houses, made yourself snacks, did your homework in front of the television, and figured out life without adults hovering. This made you independent before 'independent' was a parenting philosophy. It made you skeptical of institutions before skepticism was fashionable.

You watched Boomers get credit for Woodstock and blamed for greed. You watched Millennials get mocked for avocado toast and participation trophies. You slipped between the discourse, did your job, and went home. Nobody writes thinkpieces about Gen X. That's probably fine.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band dropped the year you were born—your parents' vinyl copy became background music to your childhood. The Summer of Love happened in San Francisco while you learned to crawl. You missed the counterculture by about seventeen years, but you inherited its wreckage: the burnt-out hippies, the curdled idealism, the macrame plant hangers.

Your actual pop culture education began with Saturday morning cartoons and never really stopped. You were two when Sesame Street premiered. Seven when The Brady Bunch ended. You watched Happy Days and Laverne & Shirley, shows set in the '50s that taught you to be nostalgic for a decade you'd never experienced. You knew the Fonz's leather jacket before you knew who the president was.

At ten, Star Wars changed everything. You saw it in theaters—probably multiple times—and the action figures became currency. Kenner couldn't make them fast enough. You had the Death Star playset, or you knew someone who did. Luke, Han, Leia, Chewie—these weren't characters, they were friends. You're still mad about Greedo shooting first.

High school was MTV. You were fourteen when it launched on August 1, 1981, and you remember the first video: 'Video Killed the Radio Star' by The Buggles. You watched music become visual. You learned the choreography to 'Thriller.' You had opinions about Duran Duran versus Depeche Mode. New Wave wasn't a genre—it was an identity.

At eighteen, The Breakfast Club arrived, and John Hughes gave your generation a voice it didn't know it needed. You watched Bender pump his fist in the air and felt something you couldn't name. Sixteen Candles, Pretty in Pink, Ferris Bueller—these weren't just movies. They were your autobiography in screenplay form. You still quote them.

Your twenties brought grunge, which felt like truth after a decade of hairspray. Nirvana's Nevermind dropped when you were twenty-four. 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' was everywhere, and Kurt Cobain looked the way you felt—exhausted, ironic, done. His death in 1994 hit harder than it should have. He was twenty-seven. You were twenty-seven. The math felt personal.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The hum of the rotary phone, heavy as a brick and tethered to the wall. The click-click-click of the dial returning to zero. The party lines in some neighborhoods where you could pick up and hear strangers talking. The technology of your childhood was physical, mechanical, and absolutely certain that someone was always listening.

At seven, you watched the pocket calculator become affordable—your dad might have bought a Texas Instruments model for $400, which seemed miraculous. By twelve, they were giving them away at banks. You learned long division by hand anyway because teachers didn't trust the machines yet. (They weren't wrong.)

Your first computer experience was probably the school's Apple II, with its green-on-black screen and that distinctive beep. Oregon Trail taught you that dysentery was funny and the West was hard. By high school, typing class meant actual typewriters—manual ones where the keys stuck and the carriage return rang like a bell. You learned to hit those keys with force.

You were seventeen when the IBM PC launched—a beige box that cost $1,565 and did less than your watch does now. Twenty-two when the Macintosh arrived with its friendly face and mouse that felt like magic. You remember computing before windows, before drag-and-drop, before any of this was intuitive. You earned these skills.

The internet entered your life somewhere in your late twenties or early thirties—CompuServe, AOL, that screech of the dial-up modem connecting. You remember email before spam, the web before pop-ups, chat rooms before anyone knew to be suspicious. You adapted to the digital age, but you remember the analog one. This makes you bilingual in a way younger people aren't.

You've lived the entire arc: from rotary phones to smartphones, from card catalogs to Google, from handwritten letters to texts that arrive in milliseconds. You remember calling Directory Assistance. You remember paper maps. You remember what it was like to be genuinely unreachable—not as a choice, but as a default. Sometimes you miss it.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were one when 1968 happened—the year Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy were shot within months of each other, the year the Democratic Convention in Chicago erupted into police violence, the year the Tet Offensive proved Vietnam was unwinnable. You don't remember any of it, but you grew up in its wreckage. The '60s idealism was already a funeral by the time you were aware.

You were seven when Nixon resigned. August 8, 1974—you probably watched it, or your parents watched it while you played in the room. A president caught lying, forced out, helicoptering away in disgrace. The lesson burned deep: authority figures cannot be trusted. This wasn't cynicism; it was observation.

You were eight when Saigon fell. The war that defined your early childhood—body counts at dinner, draft numbers on the news, older cousins coming home wrong—ended not with victory but with helicopters lifting off the embassy roof. No parade. No closure. Just exhaustion and the vague sense that America had lost something it couldn't name.

You were ten during the Bicentennial, 1976—tall ships in the harbor, fireworks everywhere, red-white-and-blue bunting on every porch. America turning 200 and trying very hard to feel good about itself. A year later, Star Wars arrived and gave your generation something pure to believe in: good versus evil, light versus dark, a galaxy that made sense.

You were thirteen when the hostages were taken in Iran, fifty-two Americans held for 444 days. You were fourteen when Reagan was shot. Seventeen when the Challenger exploded—you watched it in your classroom, the way a generation of kids watched it, Christa McAuliffe and the promise of space becoming fire and falling debris.

You were twenty-two when the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989—crowds with hammers and champagne, checkpoint guards stepping aside, strangers embracing on both sides. The Cold War you'd grown up terrified of—the drills, the bunkers, the assumption that nuclear war was when and not if—ended not with a bang but with a party. You'd been prepared for apocalypse. You got German reunification.

You were thirty-four on September 11, 2001. You were at work, probably, or about to go. Someone turned on a television. You watched the second plane hit in real time. Your kids, if you had them, were young—three, five, seven. They'd grow up in a world shaped by that morning: airport security, forever wars, orange alerts, the surveillance state. You remembered what came before. They never would.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated into the Reagan boom—not perfect, but jobs existed. The economy had emerged from the Carter-era stagflation, and employers were actually hiring entry-level workers at entry-level. 'Entry-level' meant you could learn on the job, not that you already needed three years of experience plus an unpaid internship to prove you were serious.

Your first office job probably had a typing pool, or at least the memory of one. You might have shared a phone line. You definitely didn't have email—not until your late twenties or thirties, and even then, it was a novelty. You learned to write memos, make cold calls, navigate corporate politics without the benefit of Glassdoor reviews or LinkedIn stalking.

The corporate loyalty myth died during your career. You watched it happen. Companies that promised lifetime employment laid off entire departments. 'Right-sizing' entered the vocabulary. You saw fathers with thirty years' tenure escorted out with cardboard boxes. The implicit contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was torn up while you watched. You adapted. You learned that the only job security was your own skills.

The 1987 stock market crash happened when you were twenty. The early '90s recession when you were hitting your stride. The dot-com bust when you were thirty-three. The 2008 financial crisis when you were forty-one. Each crash taught the same lesson: the floor can collapse at any moment. Each recovery taught another: you'll survive, but nobody's coming to save you.

You're the generation that learned 'work-life balance' wasn't given—it was taken. You worked the hours because the hours were expected. Sixty-hour weeks, weekend emails, vacation guilt. But somewhere in your forties or fifties, something shifted. Maybe it was watching Millennials openly prioritize life over work. Maybe it was just exhaustion. Either way, you've become pragmatic about boundaries in ways you weren't at thirty.

Now, in your late fifties, retirement feels less like a finish line and more like a math problem. Social Security's future is murky. Your 401(k) has weathered multiple storms. The pension your father counted on doesn't exist in your industry. You'll probably work longer than your parents did. You've made peace with this—or at least stopped fighting it.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Did you ever wait by the phone? Actually wait, physically near the phone, because if you weren't there when it rang, you'd miss the call? There was no voicemail in most homes—just the phone ringing into empty air. Getting someone's number was a victory. Calling meant talking to their parents first. The anxiety was real.

You learned romance through mixtapes. Hours spent recording songs off the radio, timing the DJ's voice-over, arranging tracks to tell a story without saying it directly. The Cure, The Smiths, maybe some Peter Gabriel—'In Your Eyes' playing while John Cusack held that boombox over his head. Say Anything taught your generation what love was supposed to look like. Reality was messier.

Your generation had the highest divorce rates in American history, which sounds like a failure and felt like liberation. Your parents' generation stayed in miserable marriages because divorce was shame. You watched them, and you chose differently. Women had jobs now—not just 'jobs' but careers. Leaving became economically possible. Staying unhappy stopped being the only option.

You dated before algorithms. You met people at parties, at bars, through friends of friends. There was no swiping, no profile optimization, no knowing their politics before the first drink. You had to actually talk to strangers. Some of you were good at this. Many of you were terrible. Everyone figured it out eventually.

If you're still with your first spouse, you're increasingly rare. If you're remarried, you're increasingly normal. If you're single, the dating pool is more complicated now—Tinder exists, and you've probably tried it, and it probably felt strange. You remember when meeting someone online was embarrassing. Now it's default.

Your kids, if you have them, are Millennials or early Gen Z. You raised them differently than you were raised—more present, more intentional, less sink-or-swim. You drove them to activities, monitored their homework, told them you loved them out loud. Your parents called this coddling. You called it correcting for your own childhood.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were six during the 1973 oil crisis—too young to understand, old enough to remember. Adults panicking at gas stations, the odd-even rationing based on license plates, the sense that something fundamental had broken. By the time you were twelve, inflation had peaked near 14%, mortgage rates hit 18%, and your parents talked about money in hushed, worried tones. Scarcity was your first economic lesson.

The 1987 stock market crash happened when you were twenty—October 19, Black Monday, the Dow dropping 22% in a single day. By thirty-three, the dot-com bubble burst. By forty-one, the 2008 financial crisis wiped out retirement accounts and home equity. By fifty-three, a pandemic crashed everything. You've lived through five major financial crises. The pattern is clear: disaster is regular, recovery is real, certainty is impossible.

Your generation bridged the great pension-to-401(k) shift. Your father's employer promised him a defined benefit. Your employer gave you a defined contribution and said 'good luck.' The risk transferred entirely to you—you make the investments, you absorb the losses, you hope the math works out. This was sold as freedom. It felt more like abandonment.

You bought a house when houses were still connected to salaries. The median home price when you were twenty-three was around $89,000. That same median home is now over $400,000. You got in before the ladder was pulled up. Your kids, if you have them, remind you of this when they ask why they can't afford a down payment. You don't have a good answer.

Your financial psychology is fundamentally defensive. You save because you've seen savings evaporate. You diversify because you've watched portfolios collapse. You maintain emergency funds because you know emergencies aren't theoretical. The abundance mindset that personal finance gurus recommend doesn't come naturally to you. You've seen too many floors give way.

You're in peak earning years now, statistically—late fifties, senior roles, accumulated expertise finally converting to compensation. But you're also watching the goal posts. Social Security's solvency is questionable past 2034. Medicare's future is uncertain. You can do the math. You'll probably work until seventy. You've stopped pretending otherwise.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your cynicism served you—until it didn't. You were right not to trust Nixon, right not to trust the corporations that laid off your parents, right not to trust the retirement promises that dissolved. But 'trust nothing' is a strategy, not a philosophy. It made you resilient and also passive. Sometimes things can be fixed. Sometimes collective action works. Your reflexive skepticism can become an excuse to stay on the sidelines.

You mastered self-reliance so thoroughly that asking for help feels like failure. You figured things out alone because you had to—latchkey afternoons, absent parents, institutions that didn't show up. This became identity. But not everything requires solo navigation. Sometimes the fastest solution is simply asking. You know this intellectually. Practicing it still feels uncomfortable.

You raised your children to be emotionally available because your parents weren't. But knowing something matters and modeling it are different. You told your kids to express feelings while keeping your own carefully contained. You prioritized their therapy while avoiding yours. They might be better at emotional fluency than you are—but they learned it despite you, not from you.

Your generation stepped back from the culture wars and let Boomers and Millennials fight. This felt like maturity—staying above the fray, not getting worked up, maintaining perspective. But perspective isn't the same as action. You have institutional power now. You run companies, lead departments, control budgets. You could shape the conversation. Instead, you're mostly silent. That silence is a choice.

Technology made you adaptable, but it didn't make you native. You can use the tools—sometimes better than your kids—but you miss nuances. The emotional weight of being 'left on read.' The algorithmic manipulation that shapes feeds. The way social media isn't really social at all. You see screens as tools. Younger generations see them as environments. This gap matters more than you think.

You built individual solutions to systemic problems. When jobs were unstable, you became more employable. When pensions vanished, you maximized your 401(k). When healthcare was unreliable, you prioritized jobs with benefits. This worked for you. But it doesn't work at scale. Climate change, inequality, institutional rot—these won't be solved by individual optimization. And your generation, which could be leading the systemic response, is largely absent from the fight.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1987-1997): You entered adulthood during the Reagan recovery, when jobs existed and entry-level meant you could learn on the job. The 1987 crash dented confidence but not careers—you were young enough to absorb it. The Berlin Wall fell when you were twenty-two. The Cold War ended. The future, briefly, felt open. You hustled, built careers, probably married for the first time, maybe divorced for the first time too. The world was changing faster than you could track.

Your 30s (1997-2007): The dot-com boom made millionaires of people who seemed no smarter than you. The dot-com bust reminded everyone that what goes up comes down. You were thirty-three when the towers fell, thirty-four when America invaded Iraq. If you had kids, they were young—preschool, early elementary—and you raised them in a country that felt more dangerous than the one you remembered. Your parents aged. Your career stabilized. The settling was both comfort and constraint.

Your 40s (2007-2017): The 2008 financial crisis hit just as you entered your presumptive peak earning years. Some of you lost jobs. Many lost home equity—40%, 50%, numbers that felt impossible. You rebuilt, because Gen X rebuilds, but the rebuilding was exhausting. Your kids became teenagers, then adults. Your parents needed more. You were sandwiched—responsible for generations on either side, supported by neither. This was the decade that aged you.

Your 50s (2017-2027): You're here now, navigating the aftermath of a pandemic that proved remote work was possible and also proved that management doesn't trust you anyway. Your kids are adults, mostly—launched or launching. Your parents are elderly or gone. The question of retirement has become mathematical: How much do you have? How long will you live? What will healthcare cost? The numbers rarely line up the way the retirement calculators promised.

Your 60s and beyond (2027+): Retirement, if you get there, won't look like your parents' version. No pension, no gold watch, no guaranteed anything. You'll probably work into your late sixties because the math requires it. Social Security will help, if it's there. Medicare will help, if it survives. You've made contingency plans for contingencies. This is exhausting, but it's also who you are. You survived stagflation, recessions, crashes, and a pandemic. You'll survive this too. You always do.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

3.5 million people were born in the US the same year as you—a smaller cohort than the Boomer peak, a harbinger of the Baby Bust to come. You're part of the 65 million Americans classified as Gen X, making you the smallest generation between two giants. Boomers outnumber you by ten million. Millennials by seven million. You're the demographic middle child, overlooked by marketers and ignored by pundits. This has advantages.

Compared to Baby Boomers (born 1946-1964): They believed they could change the world and, to be fair, they did—just not always in the ways they intended. They got affordable college, secure pensions, and homes that cost two years' salary. You got student loans, 401(k) roulette, and housing prices that decoupled from wages. They protested institutions. You learned to survive them. They're idealists disappointed by reality. You're realists who never expected better.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): You raised some of them, which complicates the comparison. They were helicopter-parented while you were latchkey-abandoned. They expected institutions to work; you expected them to fail. They're collaborative; you're independent. They're comfortable sharing feelings; you're still working on it. They entered the workforce during recession; you entered during expansion. Neither timing was your fault.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You might as well be from different planets. They don't remember a world before smartphones. You remember a world before answering machines. They organize collective action on social media. You organize nothing and prefer it that way. They're anxious about climate change. You're anxious too, but you've had decades of practice managing anxiety. They want systemic change. You're skeptical systems can change. This makes conversation difficult.

Your life expectancy is around 78-79 years, slightly lower than what was projected when you were born, thanks to what researchers call 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcohol. Your generation drinks more than it should, trusts less than it used to, and has quietly normalized therapy and antidepressants. The stigma your parents felt about mental health doesn't apply to you. That's genuine progress.

Your defining trait isn't idealism or optimism or even cynicism—it's adaptation. You've survived five recessions, multiple wars, a pandemic, and the complete transformation of how humans communicate. You didn't build the digital age, but you learned it. You didn't create the gig economy, but you navigated it. Whatever comes next, you'll figure it out. You always have. Nobody notices because you don't make noise about it. That's fine. You prefer it that way.

year_events: The Summer of Love peaked in San Francisco
The Beatles released Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band
Thurgood Marshall became the first Black Supreme Court Justice
The first Super Bowl was played (Green Bay won)
Dr. Christiaan Barnard performed the first human heart transplant
